item.description:
@RegeX wrote:

Fair enough, BufferedReader is more efficient because you are able to read past [100] bytes, and it will read as soon as \n is fired.

item.title: [TUT]User input
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Interesting tutorial, but using the BufferedReader class is much easier. 

java.io.BufferedReader keyboardInput = new java.io.BufferedReader(new java.io.InputStreamReader(System.in));
String inputtedString = keyboardInput.readLine();

Easier still is the Scanner class, which is new to Java 1.5:

java.util.Scanner keyboardInput = new java.util.Scanner(System.in);
String inputtedString = keyboardInput.nextLine();

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT]User input
item.dc:creator: @pistolbob pistolbob
item.description:
@pistolbob wrote:

First we must import everything we are going to use, 

import java.io*;

then we need to name the script or code lets just say "UserInput"
so now you should have something that looks like this:

import java.io.*;
class UserInput {

and now we have to have the standerd stuff that you need in every code 

public static void main (String args[])
 {

and now we need to name our bytes or variables and strings:

byte name[] = new byte[100];
  byte whatsup[] = new byte[100];
   int nr_read = 0;

Now for the program to ask a question,
i think System.out.println will work
soo lets have it say "System.out.println("What is your name?");
this will show What is your name? in the command prompt.
now for it to read your answer,

try{
nr_read = System.in.read(name);

this is telling it to read the charectors you have just typed in and save it to name.

now lets have it say "hello___"<- your name here

 System.out.print("Hello ");
System.out.write(name,0,nr_read);

this is telling it to write in Hello what you typed in as name.
to have it ask more questions you can have it say

System.out.println("whats up?");
nr_read = System.in.read(whatsup);

this will have it repeat what you said when it asked whats up.
then lets have it have another response

System.out.print("thats good.");

soo now you should have a code that looks like this

import java.io.*;
class UserInput {
  public static void main (String args[])
 {
  byte name[] = new byte[100];
  byte whatsup[] = new byte[100];
   int nr_read = 0;
  System.out.println("whats your name!?");
   try {
	nr_read = System.in.read(name);
        System.out.print("Hello ");
        System.out.write(name,0,nr_read);
        System.out.println("whats up?");
        nr_read = System.in.read(whatsup);
        System.out.print("thats good.");
    }
}

then make a new folder place it in the C drive folder or whereever
save it as UserInput.java
then go to command prompt, and type in cd whereever you saved it. mine is the C drive in a folder called java
soo i type

cd C:\java

and press enter, then i type in javac UserInput.java and this creates the .class file and then to use it, you type in java UserInput and press enter and there you go

Read full topic
